title: Five surprising stats for the 2025 San Francisco Giants
description: The Giants have seemingly disappointed offensively this season, but where do they really rank relative to the league? It may surprise you.
content:
This is an article about the San Francisco Giants’ surprising statistics, and I must warn you: They’re incredibly surprising. They’re so surprising that when I tried to publish them yesterday, the entire article disappeared. There are some things that the world simply isn’t ready for. And it had a joke about Chad Zerbe that would’ve really made you think.

Maybe that’s overselling it. These are stats that exist in the middle of a Venn diagram shared by surprising and interesting. You come into every season with a set of expectations — Patrick Bailey will have strong framing numbers, Logan Webb will have one of the highest groundball rates in the game, et cetera — and you’re proven right. For as much that’s unpredictable about baseball, there’s a lot more that’s perfectly predictable.

These are the outlier stats that made me stop and do a double take, then. The Giants are having a confusing season. Here are the numbers that aren’t helping matters.

Not surprising at all, but I’m just taking a little batting practice before the article actually starts, don’t mind me.

The 1968 Tigers had a .692 OPS. The 2000 Rockies had an .816 OPS. The ’68 Tigers scored 671 runs, and the ’00 Rockies scored 968. Which team had the better offense?

It’s a trick question, of course. It’s the Tigers, who led the American League that season in both OPS and runs scored en route to a World Series win. The 2000 Rockies finished 82-80, mostly on the strength of their pitching. OPS+ would have told us this right away, showing us that the Tigers were actually 7 percent better than the average team (107 OPS+) in 1968, while the Rockies were 13 percent worse than the average team in 2000, even though they almost scored 1,000 runs. Ballparks matter. The context of a league-wide scoring environment matters, and that environment changes every year.

Those are two outlier teams in outlier offensive seasons, but you get the idea. The league average is set at 100 OPS+. Everything above represents how much better a team is relative to the league. Everything below is how much worse they are.

The 2025 Giants, as of right now, are a perfectly average offensive team. A cool 100 OPS+, right on the nose. They’ve done some work to get there over the last two weeks, scoring eight runs or more in a third of their games, so this is a relatively recent development. Still, it’s a reminder that the Giants aren’t the complete offensive black hole that they can appear to be, especially during night games at Oracle Park.

Does that make it fun to watch them struggle to score three runs against the Pirates at Oracle on a Tuesday night? It does not. But it probably wouldn’t be that much different if an excellent offense played there instead. They would often struggle to score four runs, instead. This is just a part of Giants baseball, and it probably always will be. Some fans get to watch a lot of runs and home runs; Giants fans get one helluva view and the best ballpark in baseball.

Worth it. But the swap will occasionally lead to teams like this, where you squint and hold the computer up to your nose in disbelief? This team? This team is average at hitting baseballs?

Yep. And they should probably be even better, too.

Individual stat — Willy Adames has one of the longest swings in baseball

What’s your immediate reaction to this stat? Probably not a favorable one. I actually said “oof” out loud when I read it. That’s because, if you’re like me, you’re conditioned to think of long swings as a cautionary tale. It’s how you support a claim that a prospect will be a bust, and it’s why nobody will be surprised when it happens. His swing was too long, they’ll all say.

Except that’s not quite how it works. Adames has the sixth-longest swing in baseball. Directly above him, in fifth place, is Aaron Judge. Right behind him, in seventh place as of Thursday, is Shohei Ohtani. That’s a good set of baseball-player bookends to be in the middle of. It might be one of the best baseball-player bookends of all time. The obvious takeaway is it’s likely that long swings don’t correlate negatively with offensive production. It’s possible that they don’t correlate at all.

There’s a marked difference between Adames and those players, obviously, and not just in terms of production. Both Judge and Ohtani have elite bat speed, and Adames’ bat speed has been closer to league average. That’s the difference between a good player’s long swing and a future Hall of Famer’s long swing, so please don’t think the point of the factlet was to compare them. It just wasn’t something I knew and/or expected.

If there’s good news, it’s that Adames’ bat speed was well above average in 2024, and that combination helps explain the contract he got as a free agent. With a little more bat speed, it was a 30-homer swing, and there are all sorts of reasons why a player’s average bat speed can fluctuate, so the explanation doesn’t have to be age. It’s a possible explanation, and it could even be the Occam’s Razor-preferred one, but it’s not a given. Bat-speed tracking is still brand new to the general baseball public, so we’re all making it up as we go along.

Waaaaaaait a second, you cry. You can’t spend a couple paragraphs blathering about how the poor widdle Giants have to hit in the most extreme pitcher’s park in baseball, only to turn around and fete their pitchers for using the ballpark to their advantage. That’s double-dipping!

Sure, but there’s a difference between “Oracle Park is a reason the Giants fare well in this category” and “Oracle Park is the reason the Giants fare well,” and this team is clearly an example of the former. There are 60 home-away splits to compare the Giants to — 30 teams, each with two splits — and of those 60, the Giants are 59th in home runs allowed at Oracle Park. If there’s a surprise there, it’s only that they’re not last. (Globe Life Park and the Rangers are the new champs here, which means Bruce Bochy has seen a lot of 2-1 games in his day.) Otherwise, yeah, the Giants don’t allow home runs at Oracle Park. Big whoop.

However, their road HR/9 is almost as impressive. The rank 50th out of those 60 home-away splits, and only two teams’ away splits are better: the Dodgers and Mets. That’s pretty good company for a pitching staff to keep in 2025, and it was surprising because while the Giants still have the highest groundball rate in baseball, their gap is shrinking. They’ve had the highest GB% since 2021, sometimes with substantial margins over the second-place team. They’re essentially tied with the Mets this season, with their lowest overall rate in several seasons.

It’s going to get worse without Camilo Doval and Tyler Rogers in the bullpen. They’ve consistently had low, low home run rates, allowing just five to the 406 combined batters they’ve faced this season. For perspective, Carson Seymour has allowed that many home runs to the 48 batters he’s faced this season. So keep an eye on this stat. It’s possible that the Giants’ reign of worm-threatening domination is over.

Either way, this one caught me off-guard too because, anecdotally speaking, it’s felt like the Giants’ staff has gone through dinger-soaked stretches this season, more so than in the typical season. The numbers say no, however, which is why we keep the numbers around in the first place. It’s like J. Edgar Hoover famously said to Ginger Baker during the recording of the “Disraeli Gears” album: “There are three types of truths: Truths, super-cool truths, and statistics.”

Individual stats — Matt Chapman and Patrick Bailey have had the most important hits from any player in the 2025 season so far

This is according to a couple of nerd stats known as Win Probably Added (WPA) and Championship Win Probability Added (cWPA). When cWPA was released in 2021, I wrote about the Giants’ cWPA heroes during the championship era, and it included an explanation of how these two stats work. Go there for some nuts and bolts, if desired.

Otherwise, let’s dig in. When Chapman came up to the plate in the ninth inning of the June 7 game against the Braves, the Giants’ win probability was 9 percent based on the number of outs, the number of runners on base, the score and other factors. When his at-bat was over, the Giants had a 100-percent chance of winning the game … because they’d just won the game.

According to Baseball-Reference, no single swing did more to win a baseball game this season. That goes for all 30 teams, and what’s more is that it was the 16th-most impactful swing of the entire 2000s. It was the single-most effective swing in the history of Oracle Park. It wasn’t just your regular ol’ walk-off home run, and there are a few reasons why. There were two outs, the run-scoring environment was tough and the runner was only on first base.

However, it’s one thing to win a single game. But what about a whole danged World Series? That’s what cWPA is used for, and it takes even more factors into consideration, such as the standings at the time the game was played. When Bailey hit his walk-off inside-the-park home run, the Phillies and Giants were both in postseason position. And they were both potential wild cards at the time, which meant the system saw them as direct competitors. Taking a win away from the Phillies and giving it to the Giants made a small-but-substantial difference to each team’s hopes.

No swing has gotten their team closer to a parade than this one so far. We’re talking about the team’s odds moving by less than 1 percent, so don’t oversell it, but it still would have been an important win for a team with championship hopes. Unlike Chapman’s homer, though, this one is guaranteed to get usurped as the season goes on. There will be more important swings in August, September and, of course, October by this metric.

For now, though, remember the good times. It was also one of the objectively coolest home runs that baseball can possibly produce, which doesn’t count toward this stat, but counts in our hearts.
summary: The San Francisco Giants' statistics are so surprising that the article about them was published that it disappeared when it tried to publish them. The article discusses five surprising statistics, including that Willy Adames has one of the longest swings in baseball, which is likely to negatively impact on his offensive performance. The 1968 Tigers had a.692 OPS, while the 2000 Rockies had an.816 OPS. The league average is set at 100 OPS+. The 2025 Giants are currently an average offensive team, scoring eight or more runs in a third of their games. Despite this, the article acknowledges that the team's struggles at night games at Oracle Park are not without an offensive edge.
shortSummary: The 2025 San Francisco Giants have surprising statistics like batting average, long-lived swings, and poor defensive performance, despite being highly anticipated.

scraped_sources.text:
I’m a chaos-theory nerd. Where most people are content to remember what Cody Ross did to the Phillies, I spend more time thinking about the dominos that had to fall for Cody Ross to be on the Giants in the first place. What if Giancarlo Stanton didn’t convince the Marlins that he was ready for a full-time right field gig at the tender age of 20? What if the Marlins, who were over .500 when they waived Ross, could play for a second wild-card spot? What if Giants ownership was too frugal to block Ross from going to the Padres?
Advertisement
Don’t get me started about what happens if the Giants draft Beau Mills instead of Madison Bumgarner.
This what-if fetishization extends to what happened in the games, too. Sure, the Giants had a 3-1 series lead when Travis Ishikawa won the pennant in 2014, but what happens if he bounces into a 6-4-3 double play to end the inning, instead? The Giants might lose and head back to St. Louis with a 3-2 lead, which is still good, but maybe that just sets up the Cardinals’ version of Barry Zito. Maybe Kolten Wong looks to the sky and drinks a few raindrops at the end of Game 7.
With the specific plays, though, there’s a way to quantify the what-if. It’s not perfect, but it is fascinating, and it comes from Baseball-Reference. It’s called championship win probability, or cWPA, and although that sounds like something that makes your brain hurt, the math isn’t that convoluted.
• Assume each team has a 50 percent chance of winning every specific game
• Assume a team has a 50 percent chance of winning every specific postseason series
• Do a bunch of math for each play in every game
• Come up with a number that helps explain just how much each play affected a team’s championship hopes
Is it irrefutable science? Nope. Can I do the calculations on the back of an envelope? Nooooooooooope.
Is it cool? Heck, yeah.
Baseball-Reference’s example has to do with The Shot Heard ‘Round the World, and it’s perfect. If the Giants didn’t win that game, their season was over. If Bobby Thomson made an out, their season was almost over. If he hit a home run, they were in the World Series. His at-bat affected his team’s championship odds more than any in regular-season history. The Giants lost that World Series, but Thomson got them closer than any single play that season.
So I want to look for the cWPA plays for the Giants’ postseason series from 2010-14. Because you don’t want to know that the highest-leverage play from the 2002 World Series was actually a bloop single that Barry Bonds missed and booted. That isn’t helping anyone feel good about themselves.
Advertisement
Though it does make you think.
We’ll break this down by hitters and pitchers, and we’ll also look at each individual series. Which hits and outs were the most important in the championship runs?
Wild-card game
With just one wild-card game in the three championship runs, this isn’t going to be much of a surprise. Brandon Crawford’s grand slam was the most important at-bat of the 2014 wild-card game, of course, with a 2.41 cWPA. With one swing from Crawford, the Giants had a 4-0 lead, and it also cast Lvl. 56 Dispel on the entire crowd, which left them unable to speak for the rest of the game. It was … helpful in the team’s championship efforts.
But that doesn’t mean it was the only important part of that game. When the inning started, the Giants had a 50 percent chance of winning the game.
When Pablo Sandoval singled with no outs, the Giants had a 54 percent chance of winning the game.
When Hunter Pence followed that with a single, the Giants had a 61 percent chance of winning the game.
When Brandon Belt walked to load the bases, the Giants had a 70 percent chance of winning the game. It was the second-most important plate appearance of the game, with a 1.14 cWPA, which roughly means that the walk improved the Giants’ championship chances by a full percentage point. But Crawford’s grand slam pushed the expected winning percentage to 90 percent in the game, and the Giants didn’t look back.
When Ishikawa grounded out to second after the grand slam, the Giants’ expected winning percentage slipped by a point, which is simply unacceptable. Get it together and do something, Travis.
NLDS
Again, this stat isn’t perfect. We’re not talking science. Every part of a championship season fits together like a 10,000-piece jigsaw puzzle, and if you miss just one piece, the picture is incomplete.
Advertisement
But I love it because it’s a perfect way to appreciate some underappreciated moments. Here are the top-five NLDS moments for cWPA by the Giants from 2010-14:
1. Brandon Crawford’s triple off Mat Latos, 2012 Game 5 (4.91 cWPA)
2. Buster Posey’s ground ball to Brooks Conrad, 2010 Game 4 (4.59)
3. Aubrey Huff’s single right before that Conrad error, 2010 Game 4 (4.29)
4. Buster Posey’s grand slam off Mat Latos, 2012 Game 5 (3.36)
5. Brandon Belt’s 18th-inning HR, 2014 Game 2 (3.18)
Crawford’s triple in Game 5 of the 2012 NLDS definitely gets overlooked. If the inning ends without him scoring from third, it’s still a huge moment in the game. And if the Giants end up winning that game without Posey’s grand slam, what do you remember? It becomes the story of how it was Crawford who slew the diabolical Latos. While I can’t embed the video for technical reasons, you can watch the triple here.
I can embed this video, though:
A fair trade.
If you asked me to guess before this, I probably would have assumed the Posey grand slam was higher, but this makes sense. It’s an elimination game, which is why it’s rated higher than Belt’s homer or the Conrad play. And there’s a big difference when it comes to win probability differences between the one-run lead after Crawford’s triple and the six-run lead after Posey’s grand slam: The additional four runs are building off the initial one-run lead.
We should talk about Crawford’s triple more. According to the cold, unfeeling numbers, it added more to a Giants championship run than anything else they’ve done in the NLDS.
NLCS
You want upsets? Here’s an upset:
1. Juan Uribe’s home run, 2010 Game 6 (7.87 cWPA)
2. Marco Scutaro first-inning single, 2012 Game 7 (4.82)
3. Matt Cain’s second-inning single, 2012 Game 7 (4.75)
4. Michael Morse’s home run, 2014 Game 5 (4.70)
5. Travis Ishikawa’s home run, 2014 Game 5 (4.40)
Advertisement
The upset isn’t the first one. You might have guessed Uribe’s home run.
But Scutaro hitting a single in the first inning of Game 7 in the 2012 NLCS that moved Ángel Pagán from first to third? Matt Cain’s single the next inning? I had to be reminded of these moments. And it’s at this point that you’re ready to give up on the stat.
Don’t. I can explain! It’s all about the importance of a Game 7.
If Ishikawa pops out in the 2014 pennant-clincher, the Giants’ championship chances take a hit. But that would have been the second out of the inning. Maybe Crawford singles to win the pennant in the next at-bat. Or maybe he walks, and then Matt Duffy comes up as a pinch-hitter and gets hit by a pitch. Or maybe Andrew Susac hits a pinch-hit homer in the 16th inning. Or maybe Posey drives in seven runs in Game 6. Or maybe Bumgarner hits a go-ahead home run in Game 7.
If Scutaro makes an out, the Giants have 26 potential outs left in their season. Every out that doesn’t lead to a run is an out that gets them closer to elimination. A team scores an average of 0.56 runs when they have a runner at first and one out. When they have runners at first and third and nobody out, they score an average of 1.8 runs. It’s a huge shift in the inning.
There’s more. I don’t know the exact record, but teams that have been held scoreless have never won a single postseason game. It’s true! So even just the potential one run gives the Giants a much better chance of winning Game 7. And winning Game 7 gives the Giants a 50-50 shot at winning the World Series, which is way better than the Cardinals had after that game.
There you have it. Put some respect on Cain’s single while you’re at it. It came with two outs, and it doubled the Giants’ lead. They had a 66 percent win probability before his single and a 75 percent win probability afterward. That might not seem like a lot, but when it comes to Game 7 — and the chances of winning a World Series after that — it’s bigger than it gets credit for.
Advertisement
The math says so.
World Series
And you can’t argue with math. Can you?
1. Michael Morse’s game-winning single, 2014 Game 7 (11.45 cWPA)
2. Pablo Sandoval’s two-out, bases-loaded single, sixth inning of 2014 Game 4 (9.54)
3. Brandon Belt’s single to load the bases, second inning of 2014 Game 7 (7.74)
4. Edgar Rentería’s danged home run, 2010 Game 5 (7.53)
5. Aubrey Huff’s home run, 2010 Game 4 (6.15)
The top moment from the 2012 World Series was Sandoval’s second homer off Justin Verlander, in case you were wondering. But when it comes to pushing the Giants closer to a championship, nothing he ever did can top his RBI single from the sixth inning of Game 4 in 2014.
Which you definitely remember. Right?
I mean, I was covering the game. So I definitely remember it like it was yesterday.
Gimme one second.
Of course, of course, of course. I really do remember it right now, and the whole comeback is starting to, well, come back to me. The Giants were in a pickle in Game 4, and then they rallied. Then they rallied some more. And then a right-handed hitting (!) Sandoval got them out in front, and they ended up running away with the game.
If Sandoval makes an out, the Giants might go down 3-1 in the series. With the single, they had an 86-percent chance of winning.
If Rentería makes an out in Game 5 of the 2010 fall classic, maybe the Giants win the World Series at home, with Tim Lincecum hitting a pinch-hit inside-the-park home run. You don’t know what was stolen from you, you just don’t.
OK, fine, I am also just a little skeptical when it comes to ranking Sandoval’s single over Rentería’s home run. And that’s before we get to Belt’s Game 7 single from 2014, which is third on that list, even though it didn’t lead to a run at all.
The overall idea makes sense, though. If you’re trying to compute a path to winning the World Series, a ninth-inning homer in Game 1 of the NLDS is worth less than a ninth-inning homer in Game 7 of the NLCS. And once you’re OK with that distinction, then you can get used to the idea of a fourth-inning single in the World Series being more valuable than a ninth-inning homer in the NLCS. Or that same single getting more credit than an actual World Series-winning homer from 2010.
So, in sum, here are the most important at-bats in Giants’ postseason history from 2010-14.
| Series | Game | Inning | Event | cWPA |
|---|---|---|---|---|
|
2014 WS
|
Game 7
|
t4
|
Michael Morse single
|
11.45%
|
|

|

|
b6
|
Pablo Sandoval single
|

|
|

|

|
t8
|
Juan Uribe home run
|

|

|

|

Don’t yell at me. Yell at the math. And don’t yell at the math because we’re just having fun here. There were still a lot of ways for the Giants to win the World Series if Rentería strikes out in 2010, but there were far fewer ways to win if Morse doesn’t punch an RBI single to right field in 2014. I’d never thought of it like that, but I sure do now.
Advertisement
You don’t have to give up your favorite postseason moments. Just know that we have a new way to appreciate some of the moments that might have been forgotten otherwise.
So, where were you when Matt Cain hit his single?
It was one of the biggest moments in San Francisco Giants history, after all.
(Photo: Jose Carlos Fajardo / Bay Area News Group via Getty Images)

argos_summary: The San Francisco Giants are experiencing a perplexing season, currently holding an average offensive performance with a 100 OPS+. Despite struggles at their home park, Oracle Park, their pitching staff has maintained low home run rates, ranking well in both home and away splits. Notable individual performances include Matt Chapman and Patrick Bailey, who have delivered crucial hits that significantly impacted the team's win probabilities this season.
